ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: The class moves fairly quickly, and it was stressful trying to work out the problems in class that the professors would give you. I had talked to a friend that had taken the class in a previous year, and my friend said that he would always feel rushed to do these problems and would never be able to keep up with the pace of the ckass. I felt I had a similar experience. I think the idea of the course is good and should continue since a lot of physics ph.d. students need to be proficient with c++ for their work. For this reason I would recommend the course.
If you are in physics and need to learn C++, this is the class. It's not the best, but it's the one they offer.
For a broad education on programming, including everything you need to know, this is the course for you.
I would strongly recommend this course to other students, especially students doing particle and nuclear physics research.
Yes, I would definitely recommend it.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Programming is an essential skill that I need to develop for research, so this course attempted to teach to that.
I need to know a lot of C++ for my research, so it was good to get a better grasp of the basics.
It gave me the skills that I will need to conduct my research.

The materials covered in this class are what I will encounter in my research. The class gives me almost everything I need in C++. Most important, I feel confident now and is able to learn further knowledge by myself in the future.
I have done some programming for research, and as we move into data analysis and I am programming more and more I know it will be very helpful.
